newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine T-bills yields to slip more, dealers say.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine T-bills yields to slip more, dealers say.

text.p: Ukraine's Finance Ministry will be able to cut yields further at auctions of Treasury bills due to increased demand caused by a forthcoming 30 percent tax on T-bill earnings, dealers said on Monday.
Ukrinbank's Ivan Budko said investors were purchasing larger quantities of the paper before the tax comes in on July 1.

Average yields at the latest auctions last week slipped to 19.83 percent from 20.25 percent on six-month paper, to 28.26 percent from 28.54 percent on nine-month paper, and to 30.85 percent from 28.28 percent on 12-month paper.
Budko said yields on nine-month bills would drop more quickly than on 12-month bills due to higher demand at recent auctions.
"It's possible, maybe not at the next auction but soon after, that the Finance Ministry will lower yields on nine-month bills to 26 percent from 28.26 percent," Budko said.
Ukraine's central bank will auction six-month, nine-month and 12-month discount Treasury bills on June 10.
Perkombank's Serhiy Matveychuk said the ministry appeared to be trying to bring yields on nine-month bills to about 25 percent, and to 28 percent on 12-month paper.

But he said the speed at which this would be accomplished depended on passage of the budget, an official announcement of a currency corridor, and participation of the central bank in purchasing Treasury-bills.
"If the budget were accepted, then you would see an obvious drop in one to two weeks," he said.
Ukraine is expecting to raise 3.3 billion hryvnias from T-bills to cover its deficit, which the much-delayed budget has forecast at 5.7 billion hryvnias.
Dealers said Ministry of Finance would not sell three-month bills until passage of the budget, expected by the end of the month.
"Maybe someone would buy three-month bills at 15 percent, but the Finance Ministry does not want to sell them below 22 percent," Matveychuk said.
The ministry stopped sales of three-month bills in mid-May when yields stood at 21.15 percent.

Mykola Shevchenko, a T-bill analyst at Kinto Securities and Investments, forecast a drop of about half a percent on yields of six-, nine-, and 12-month paper because the government had recently made large payments and earnings on T-bills.

"Last week the government covered large T-bill payments of 49 million hryvnias and it earned 181 million hryvnias in budget revenues," Shevchenko said, adding it was due to pay out 70 million hryvnias this week.
Annual inflation has been forecast at about 25 percent this year against 39.7 percent in 1996.

Ukraine's deputy prime minister in charge of the economy Serhiy Tyhypko announced a currency corridor, or trading band, for the hryvnia of 1.70 to 1.90 to the dollar in April, but higher government officials have since denied existence of a formal corridor. ($1 = 1.8590 hryvnias)
